description: From Middle English forseen, forsen, from Old English forsēon (“to look down upon, despise”), equivalent to for- +‎ see. Compare Old Saxon farsehan, Old High German farsehan (Middle High German versehen).

verbs.description: forsee (third-person singular simple present forsees, present participle forseeing, simple past forsaw, past participle forseen)

entries.meaning: (transitive, UK dialectal, Scotland) To neglect; overlook; disregard; despise.

examples: The reasone why the Commissioner did so muche presse the reading of the declinator was, because he forsaw that they meant to putt him to a dilemma which still should bring ane inconvenience along with it [...]

entries.meaning: (transitive, UK dialectal, Scotland) To oversee; superintend; direct.
